captions.text:
Good morning Hank, it's Wednesday. It is morning,
but it is once again night-morning, as you
can see - oh look! Jupiter!

All right Hank, it is nearly dawn in Roscoe,
New York.

Readers of the book will likely know from
the setting that it's a pretty serious day,

so I don't think I'm gonna be messing around
too much with Nat and Cara today. Instead,
let's talk about the Project for Awesome.
Cara: Hiiiiiiii!
So Hank, the Project for Awesome -
C &others: Hiiiiii! (laughter)

So -
Hiiii!

so -
Hiiii!

so
Hiiii!

So Hank, the Project for Awesome is a -
So Hank, the Project for Awesome is a
hiiiii!

That's Nat Wolff, who plays Q in the movie,
and, um, John Lennon, who plays Margo Roth
Spiegelman.

Nat: I'm improvising now.
(Laughter from John).

Cara: Heeey Macarena!
To the left!

One maca-two-maca-three-macarena, nanananana,
heeey macarena!

John: Right! So the Project for Awesome is
an annual charity event in which the Nerdfighter

community tries to decrease world suck and
increase world awesome.

Nat: Uh, the Project for Awesome will be on
December 12th and 13th, which is actually

4 days away from my birthday. 4 and 5 days
away from my birthday.
When's your birthday?
December 17th.

That's when the Project for Awesome usually
is, but we had to move it because it's the
end of the Paper Towns shoot.
Cara: Because it's his birthday!!!!

Nat: Yeah, it's my birthday!
John: Yeah, we gotta focus on Nat's birthday

that day.
Yay!
Nat: Yeah, project for Nat.

I thought this change might be better received
if it came from, you know, Nat and Carr - oh

- this just got so weird. I'm having such
an unpleasant experience.

So we're moving the Project for Awesome to
December 12th mostly because of the Paper

Towns shoot but also because of Nat's birthday.
I'm sorry about that, but I, I really want
to be part of it.

But Hank, we also want to talk to Nerdfighteria
about maybe doing other things differently,
beginning with comments.

So the Project for Awesome started out in
2007 with YouTubers making videos about, like,

charity, instead of, you know, cats on Roombas
or whatever.

This is back when people discovered YouTube
videos primarily on, like, the "Most Discussed
Page" or the "Top Rated Page."

Nerdfighteria came together to essentially
hijack YouTube's algorithm. And that was amazing,

back when those pages existed. But then, YouTube
made comments progressively less important

to discovery. Basically, comments spamming
just doesn't work anymore.

I dunno where to vlog from so I think I'll
go to this creepy abandoned building.

So the other challenge that we have is that
traditionally, 100% of the Project for Awesome's

money goes to charities chosen by Nerdfighteria
at projectforawesome.com.

So this is a great system, but two things:
first, it's hard to get, like, matching money

from wealthy private donors. And second, because
we're all always so busy comment-spamming,

I think that sometimes there isn't enough
attention paid to the actual, like, voting
for charities.

So here is my proposal, and Nerdfighteria,
I want your feedback about this, any new ideas
you might have...

The first day of the Project for Awesome,
we raise money for three organizations that

are known to be excellent and efficient when
it comes to combating global poverty and disease.

This will allow us to get a lot of matching
donations, like potentially hundreds of thousands

of dollars, and also to decrease a known cause
of world suck.

And then the second day of the Project for
Awesome will be all about raising money for

charities chosen by Nerdfighteria, and instead
of comment-spamming, we'll have, like, meaningful

discussions in comments of Project for Awesome
videos.

So to summarize, Hank, here is my proposal:
December 12th and 13th instead of December

17th and 18th. On December 12th, at noon Eastern,
everyone who wants to uploads a video about

a charity of their choice. Members of the
Nerdfighter community try to watch as many

of those videos as possible, have substantive
discussions in comments, and then all of Nerdfighteria

votes carefully and thoughtfully for their
favorite charities at projectforawesome.com.

All of the money raised after the first day
of the Project for Awesome will go to those

charities, all of the money raised on the
first day that are well-regarded in the field
of global health and poverty.

And I can't decide if I should go in this
door. I kind of want to.
Oh, it's a bathroom! Oh, it's quite lovely.

We've experimented a lot with the format and
scope of the Project for Awesome over the

years, but one thing has never changed: it
is my favorite time of year to be a Nerdfighter,

and I can promise you: this year, the perks
are going to be amazing.

I'm going to go back to the movie set, I will
see you- this is the last time I get to say
this, it's kind of a bummer- tomorrow.

title: The Future of the Project for Awesome: Pizzamas Day 8

comments.author: a british guy

comments.text:
An important benefit, especially for smaller charities, is just the 
visibility gained by being able to upload a video about their cause and 
having people actively looking for and watching their videos. Could we make 
sharing on other social media sites a part of P4A? For small charities, it 
seems to me that the visibility is really the most important part.

BTW, P4A is OUTSTANDING and just watching your videos gets me super pumped! 
Thanks for being AWESOME!﻿
comments.author: Christopher Feltner

comments.text:
If +John Green  or +Hank Green have responded to any comment I haven't seen 
it.

It was only weeks ago John talked about struggling to find ways to more 
meaningfully connect to Nerdfighteria. 

The Truth: John and Hank have gotten a lot of attention for building an 
organic meaningful audience, And the pressures of family, money, & exposure 
have drawn them away from the community somewhat. 

There has always been a tension between their celebrity and the organic 
community they try to build.

With John's kids, Hollywood movie success, Crash Course, Bill Gates, Hank 
Green and the Perfect Strangers, etc ... The VlogBrothers seems to loose 
out to other priorities.

It's understandable. They can't be all things to all people. They have 
given us a community we can be so proud of, and that should never be lost. 
Nerdfighters forever.

But yeah, a major change is dropped for their giant annual charity event. 
It is received with massive backlash, and neither John nor Hank seem to be 
around to participate in the discussion.

We are a long way away from the day when John started a video with 30 
seconds of silence to deliberately drive away un-engaged people. 

It is what it is. I hope for good things to come.

I won't be donating on the first day. I encourage anyone who feels the same 
way to save their donations for the second day. ﻿
comments.author: David Carroll

comments.text:
I personally love the idea of commenting meaningfully on charities we 
ourselves choose, but I dislike the idea of giving three well known 
charities all the profits of the first day. For one, those charities 
receive rather substantial donations throughout the year, and many have 
school groups, and private fundraisers. The P4A allows the lesser known 
charities to receive donations. However, I think that instead of the three 
charities on the first day to be per-determined, the candidates are 
predetermined, and we vote for those, as well.﻿
comments.author: Musea Chang

comments.text:
I think, before you ask the people Nerdfighteria to give an ok, perhaps we 
should know who the big charities are, to see if we agree that they are 
transparent, helpful, and useful charities. In other words-to tell us what 
we are voting for. We want to know our money is going to an amazing place, 
and under the previous formatting, we were allowed to make these kinds of 
decisions, although they were, perhaps, occasionally railroaded by popular 
voting rather than educated voting.  And while I trust you, I don't trust 
many big charities.  So, for example, Save the Children or Water.org have 
often received a part of the pie through Nerfighteria's voting system.  I'd 
be willing to bend for them. But, someone like the Komen fund, not so much.

However, I'm also worried that because of the donations to the big 
charities, the little charities will not receive as much.  The big 
charities have big marketing campaigns that bring in money year round, and 
the matching companies are going to match other people and perhaps the same 
charities, but the little charities don't have these kinds of machines to 
bring the money in. For many, this is their big chance to make a difference 
for the year.  I'd hate to see that chance dwindle.

I'm sorry if my thoughts are a bit messy.  I'm very tired, and maybe sick, 
but those are my personal worries.﻿
comments.author: RinnsKitchen

comments.text: This man can speak extremley fast!﻿
comments.author: AnotherEmi

comments.text:
Question for future P4As, can nerdfighters pitch ideas for charities that 
don't exist yet? Allocating more funds for more impactful charities day 1 
and having more options day 2 makes sense. But decreasing world suck should 
have as few inhibitors to innovation as possible, especially in a community 
with so few limitations and so many awesome innovators and creators. 

I myself and I imagine hundreds if not thousands have ideas to start new 
unheard of organizations or charities to address current problems that are 
being ignored. Consider having a day for those innovators to pitch the 
community their ideas and select a few to get behind. 

This would encourage more collaboration, more creativity in the face of 
world suck, and could empower this community to engage with the difficult 
problems in their own experiences/environments in another way.﻿
comments.author: Brianna Palmore

comments.text: Ah, my birthday is dec 17 too!!﻿
comments.author: Jenna.h.k

comments.text:
I'm not sure about having the first day go to pre-determined charities. I 
love the idea that Nerdfighters pitch the charities and choose them. There 
is something about that community act that makes this a special kind of 
fundraiser. We have raised so much money without wealthy private downers in 
the past, and I don't think there willingness to donate should dictate how 
P4A is set up. ﻿
comments.author: Carly Friesen

comments.text:
I've actually been thinking about this a lot lately. I didn't really want 
to post anything until I had sorted out my thoughts more, so sorry this 
comment is a little bit late. I've been participating in the P4A since 
2007. I have seen it change and grow over the years in many amazing ways.
I do agree that spamming via comments no longer actually works, which makes 
me so sad. I think meaningful conversations sound like a nice idea, and I 
might add in that it may be a good idea to hijack other social media sites 
(twitter, facebook, whatever else people use these days) because I feel 
like spreading awareness about charities is a core part of the P4A.
Initially I was a little unsure about donating to the 3 big charities the 
first day, but after considering it and reading some of the other comments 
I have somewhat come around to the idea. I think it is okay to involve big 
charities, as it will allow for more donations going to good charities and 
thus doing more good. The P4A has always been different in that it really 
supports the underdogs and often gives money to charities who wouldn't 
normally get big donations. I don't want that part to change. I guess I 
wonder if the large corporations wouldn't donate to these charities anyway, 
and does making that a part of the P4A actually make a difference in how 
much money is being donated?
Honestly, the biggest problem I am still having has to do more with the 
fact that we are allocating all of the first days funds to bigger 
charities. Most donations come in on the first day, and some people won't 
want to donate to bigger charities. Now, lots of people will just say "well 
then save your money and donate the second day" which sounds perfectly 
reasonable... except when you add in the perks (I am assuming you are still 
planning to have perks for donations?). Lots of the perks are limited and 
may go fast. Let's consider a hypothetical situation where a person wants 
to donate to smaller charities so they plan to wait until day 2, but a perk 
comes up on day 1 that they want and if they wait until day 2 it'll 
probably be gone. This person is left to choose between a perk they are 
interested in and where they want their money to go. I'm not sure if there 
is a good way to work around that. I suppose you could not have perks the 
first day, but that would probably result in significantly fewer day 1 
donations. Possibly there might be a way to allow people donating for perks 
to decide if they want their money to go to the first or second day fund 
(like a pending donation?). Or this just might have to be a decision people 
have to make.
So yea, those are my general thoughts about this. Thanks for reading :)﻿

comments.text:
HEY and also... what if we had a P4A +1 day? Maybe that would alleviate 
some of the concerns that people have about losing out on the project as it 
stands. I don't know how that would work with the Live Stream. So Maybe 
Friday+Saturday are the same as they have been traditionally and then day 
THREE becomes an exciting race to the finish line where Nerdfighteria can 
raise a bunch of money for the big three... like a Day Three For The Big 
Three thing. Maybe there's a way for the Big Three to be picked out of the 
winning ten for days one and two... like we have three categories to be 
filled and those are poverty, disease, and hunger and then people who have 
videos on those three categories would be encouraged to tell why their 
charity deserves to be one of the Big Three. We could even vote on the 
categories ahead of time (because Nerdfighteria loves a vote). Think of it 
as a test run for next year, then... see how we do when we're challenged to 
raise the "then some" while maintaining our regularly scheduled 
charity-sharing.﻿
comments.author: Julia Tindell

comments.text:
Having listened to some podcasts on how both charity $s and aid $s can be 
used less and more efficiently depending on where the $ goes I have to say 
as much as I love the old model for P4Awesome I think this is a good, 
necessary and smart idea. Not all charities are able to use public funds 
efficiently and some non-profits may have a big support base to vote for 
them but not necessarily do as much "in the public good" as others. As 
Nerdfighters our biggest priority should be doing the much awesome as we 
can, so yeah gotta back this proposal. ﻿
comments.author: Kacey Martin

comments.text:
Fantastic point, we should definitely be encouraging people to provide this 
sort of info in their video, especially because I think there would be a 
lot of Nerdfighters who go on to donate to charities they see in the videos 
at other times of the year or directly to the charity (I fall into both 
categories because I'm Australian so donations to the 
foundationtodecreaseworldsuck aren't tax deductible here as far as I know - 
most US charities aren't - and the time of year is a bit tricky, I tend to 
donate more in November/April/June).
comments.author: Kacey Martin

comments.text:
Maybe this is something people should be encouraged to address in their 
videos! For example, I'm doing a video for Breaking Free this year and I 
know that at least 75% of the funding they take in goes directly toward 
services for women and girls. While 25% goes to fundraising, 
administrative, and other costs, I like to remember that the organization 
actively and deliberately employs a number of survivors--it's a 
survivor-led organization, from the Receptionist to the Executive Director. 
Maybe including that sort of information in our videos would make us more 
likely to research and would make us more likely to vote for the charities 
that WILL be doing good stuff with their cash! :)
comments.author: Julia Tindell

comments.author: Erin Hernandez

comments.text:
The thing that is broken about voting for #p4a  is how soon the voting 
closes. Most people can't actually watch all the videos live. The quick end 
to voting means the later videos don't have time to be shared among 
thoughtful voters. 

PS. Splitting the dollars between the vote and pre-selected charities is 
fine. Getting more money for good causes is a good thing. Just remember, 
#p4a   isn't just about raising money, it's also about getting people 
involved and exposed to the charity scene, and having lots of matching 
dollars from outside the community doesn't really contribute to that.﻿
comments.author: David Carroll

comments.text: Double thumbs up for your suggestions John! ﻿
comments.author: Trisarahtops519

comments.text:
So, in preparation for my comment I went back and watched videos about the 
2007 Power Project for Awesome. In his 2007 video, Hank describes PP4A as 
awesome because every Nerdfighter involved was promoting a charity of their 
choice that they believed reduced the amount of suck in the world. The goal 
back then was to fill youtube with the things that we care about and raise 
some money in the process. And I think that’s where my problem with this 
plan comes in.

John’s suggestion to spend a day raising money for three pre-determined 
charities is valuable, but I think the thing that makes me feel weird about 
it is that at that point it ceases to be P4A and starts being just a 
fundraiser. And there’s nothing wrong with a fundraiser!! But that’s 
something we can do any ol’ time of the year.

The way I’ve always understood it, P4A is about individuals digging deep to 
determine what charities they want to share with Nerdfighteria in order to 
raise awareness and invite each other to reduce world suck. It’s about 
having important discussions about the value of charity and educating one 
another about the problems plaguing our world today. During P4A, the 
community chooses who deserves contributions based on the quality of the 
charities and the qualities of the videos being made. Having a focus on 
three pre-determined charities makes it less democratic and implies that 
the international charities that might be chosen are inherently more 
valuable and worthy of donations than any charity a Nerdfighter might want 
to talk about during P4A. And that’s just not right.

Finally, I just want to say: I know that matching donations are exciting 
and valuable, but Nerdfighteria is too powerful to discount simply because 
it's hard to match general fundraising with grants that usually call for 
specific things. Call us to do something amazing this year and we will rise 
to the occasion. Expect us to donate little, and we will happily donate 
little. Expect us to donate much, and we will fight to the gritty end until 
we have come out victorious. But in order to unlock our potential, you have 
to believe in us first.﻿
comments.author: Julia Tindell

comments.text:
I'm really not sure about the predetermined charities. I think a really 
cool part of project for awesome is seeming some amazing, yet unknown, 
charities benefit from the nerd fighter community. Getting lots of money 
for the well known charities is fantastic, but I think the amount of people 
participating will drastically diminish because of it. The whole appeal of 
P4A is that we get to be an integral part in selecting the charities and 
see the difference we make. With larger charities that have money already 
coming in, we'll get lost in the scope of things and perhaps not see a 
change, like we do with the smaller ones. ﻿

What I like about comments earning money is that it is a way young people

comments.author: Jordan Funkler

comments.text:
SO...here's the thing, "Nerdfighteria's" favorite charities are well known, 
but what I like about the P4A livestreams and comment spamming is that our 
attention is drawn to little known charities or causes that might spark our 
interest.  Like there are people who come up with great videos to encourage 
donations for their Relay for Life team, or for a particular program at 
their personal school, or to tell people about their experience registering 
for the bone marrow donation register.  The peons of the YouTube community 
care as much about their causes as the big names, and still deserve the 
attention and respect even though the "algorithm" no longer works.﻿
comments.author: froregon

comments.text: My boyfriend has definitely forgotten to go online for Pizzamas. ﻿
comments.author: TheMKThornton

comments.text: Nat Wolff's birthday is the day before mine!!!!!!﻿
comments.author: LOLchickerz

comments.text:
I don't think this idea is horrible. And it's hard, without sitting down 
with Hank and John, to have a productive conversation about it.  However, I 
do feel like we, as a community, could partner with a larger organization, 
like we did with water.org, at any time to raise money. (This is also a 
thing many nerdfighters already do outside the community) But P4A is about 
supporting smaller charities handpicked by nerdfighters.  Getting large 
sums of "matching money from wealthy private donors" seems like a great 
idea but many of these people have a chosen amount of money that they will 
donate to a charity regardless of the P4A. I really think that our focus 
shouldn't be on drastically increasing the amount of money we raise, 
honestly the money has been doing that on its own pretty well for the last 
seven or so years of the P4A. We should instead place it on helping smaller 
charities in need of support with causes we agree with. I'm open to being 
wrong though.﻿
comments.author: Satisfyedeyes

comments.text:
I'm not really a video making type of person but there's a charity that you 
really need to consider!!  You've probably already heard about Partner's In 
Health because you've probably read Mountains Beyond Mountains, but if you 
haven't stop what you're doing and read it right this second!  Paul Farmer 
and his team have not only had an enormous impact on the lives of millions 
of people living in rural Haiti, but they're changing the way international 
aid organizations should be run.  This book will change the way you think 
about charitable giving and non profits as well as the social and 
anthropological issues of poverty.  Please consider Partners In Health as a 
charity for either of the day of Project For Awesome, as every single penny 
with be used thoughtfully and will do so much good for people who need it!﻿
comments.author: Hope Anderson

comments.author: Conner Fields

comments.text:
Raising more money for charities through matching donations seems like a 
good idea because decreasing world-suck is the most important part of the 
P4A but as a nerdfighter I really want to feel involved in the 
community and from discussions and comments it seems like a lot of other 
people care about involvement too. I don't know how big donation matching 
is organized but would it be possible to choose several big charities 
(maybe including some big charities that have won in past P4A's like 
Water.org and Doctors Without Borders) and then the nerdfighters could vote 
for the three big finalists? (This would probably be done a few weeks in 
advance). I hope we can find some sort of compromise, I'm really excited to 
participate in my first P4A, DFTBA! ﻿
comments.author: CreativityJune

comments.text:
I have never done a project for awesome video. I would like to do one this 
year about a charity about an hour from me. They pair rescue dogs with 
soldiers with PTSD. It's a great charity because it helps dogs and 
soldiers. The dogs get to live and the soldiers get unconditional love and 
comfort that helps them be able to live more normal lives again. This 
charity is almost like a two in one. How often does that happen?﻿
comments.author: hena1937

comments.text:
I love both the idea of attracting more matched donations as well as 
keeping the P4A democratic and interactive, so as long as both are involved 
I don't mind how. But my preference would probably be just to give money to 
six charities at the—three big ones that are pre-chosen and three that are 
voted in—rather than separating it by days.﻿
comments.author: sn0wflake

comments.text:
What seems like it's being missed in these comments is *which* "Big" 
charities will be involved in the first day. I'm all in favor of making the 
P4A a little more predictable. Part of being democratic is giving 
individuals some more clarity in where their money will go, and the 
proposal for Day 1 does that in a way that could increase the size of the 
P4A, even if it doesn't actually increase the total amount of charity.

That said, if they're being chosen by John and Hank, that abandons much of 
the democratic motivation for the P4A. And much as John's time with Bill 
Gates may have given him time to reflect on the subject, their preferences 
for charities aren't invariably good or evidence-based. .﻿

the rationale is sound and I appreciate the matching aspects. How would the 
known "larger" charities be chosen? If we vote beforehand, I don't mind. 
There are a lot of charities that nerdfighteria have supported in the past 
that I feel good about, but I also feel like it is kind of taking the power 
away from the people because the videos don't mean as much for the 
charities.﻿

comments.text:
I will miss the insanity that accompanies spamwowing but I do think these 
ideas will foster more complex engagements with the videos (and the 
conversations they provoke) and with the voting, which I think hasn't 
gotten the attention it deserves in the past. I am concerned about the 
weighting of day one versus day two, but I know the team will space out 
perks and so on so that the majority of the money doesn't come on the first 
day. I'm sure whatever charities are selected for the first day will be 
great ones since presumably you all will be doing that choosing? (Or will 
we vote on that somehow ahead of time?) Thanks for starting this 
conversation.﻿

comments.author: Emmi Harrison

comments.text:
Having three predetermined charities is understandable, I do have one 
question, though. And this is less about the splitting of funds from the 
two days and more about the charity themselves; why can we only promote a 
charity during P4A and not a specific project said charities have? Ex: I 
know most people are familiar with UNICEF, and it is a great (and pretty 
"excellent and efficient") charity, however UNICEF has had several projects 
over the years that are specific in what cause they help, like the 
Eliminate Project (which aims to eliminate maternal and neonatal tetanus 
(MNT)) or The Six Cents Initiative (aiming to bring clean water in 
developing countries). Both are great causes, but donating to UNICEF itself 
splits the funds one might donate to them between their individual projects 
as well as just administrative costs. However, if you donate to the 
specific project you are donating to that cause alone, and you then know 
where your money is going and if it is going to the cause you wish to 
support. Would it not be more understandable to have P4A not only promote 
charities but also their projects? I don't know if there is a reason that 
P4A is just for the charities and not the projects, if there is please tell 
me! Thank you. ﻿
